my little brother is not dying on my watch
summary: I don’t care. You just want your Loki back, don’t you, and I just want my Thor back, and Wilson Fisk and Ebony Maw and Other and...
text: I don’t care. You just want your Loki back, don’t you, and I just want my Thor back, and Wilson Fisk and Ebony Maw and Other and Ronan don’t sound like such a good combination, and I think any Loki and any Thor - us included - can beat their uglies names and take asses - ah, Mantis taught me and so… when do we start?
source: “My Little Brother Is Not Dying On On My Watch and that’s Final, chapter 42

title: Running From My Shadow
body:
Loki has escaped the Asgard prison, again.

Soft Praise To a Hard Lie

It had become one of his favorite hobbies, if not the only one. Sneaking out of prison every other day was something that filled Loki with joy, whether it was to steal something or play pranks on Thor…

Read more…

blog.name: boredbrooder
blog.title: Another Marvel Fangirl
blog.description: Hello, this is my first time on Tumblr.  The Marvel universe has been out for a decade now, and I've always been a fan -- especially of Asgard, and especially of the princes, and especially of Loki.  Lately, I've become obsessed with Marvel -- especially of Asgard, and especially with the princes, and especially with Loki.  I've got theories and fanfic and everything.  I joined tumblr just to share these ideas with you.  I hope you enjoy.  But if you don't, please be kind.  I hate vulgarity.

title: Merry Mischief
body:
For River’s Holiday Challenge

image by @maniploki

Chris exited the elevator in a short green dress and black leggings, orange fringe falling in her face again, arm looped around her boyfriend.  It had taken some effort, but she finally managed to convince Loki to come to the party.  He had found a nice green tunic and black slacks.  His shoulder-length raven curls looked immaculate against the tunic.

An old man in a veteran’s cap and a young blond woman hurried into the elevator behind them.  People were everywhere, standing, chatting and holding drinks.  They passed a man with braces on his knees and back.  He was wearing nice slacks and a winter-themed polo shirt.  “Boom, ya’ lookin’ fo dis?” he said to a round of chuckles.  Apparently, his story had been funny.

“I don’t see why I didn’t receive an invitation directly from Tony?” Loki whined for the um-teenth time.  “Every one of them agreed I was as much an Avenger now as any of them.  Yet, they still don’t trust me.”

“It’s all your titles,” Chris explained absently, shaking the hand of a tipsy dignitary.  “Liesmith, god of mischief, bringer of chaos.  They’re afraid of you.”  She spoke lightly enough, but really she hoped her words would comfort the gloomy god.  She was seldom afforded the opportunity to attend such illustrious events and she was determined to enjoy herself, even if Loki didn’t.

“Yes, well, the god of thunder sounds equally as frightening, along with his less familiar name, cosmic oaf.”  Loki smiled sardonically as they passed into the first room from the elevator hall.  They passed a wall-sized TV and several teenagers sitting on fluffy furniture.

“You can’t do that, Peter,” a pretty girl cried as she laughed.

“Oh, yes I can, Princess,” Peter replied.  These two were holding controllers while the wall-screen showed a split view of two cars.

“Yeah, you show her Peter,” said a chubby Asian, supporting his best friend.  A brown-haired youth playing with glowing red mist seemed to support the princess.

“I should in with that group,” Loki pouted as they left the teens behind.  “I’m closer comparatively to their age than to yours.  Yet they never invite me to – what’s the Earth vernacular – hang out?”

“They used to invite you, but you kept turning them down, remember?  Something about them being immature and primitive?”  Chris took a moment to bow to a dark-skinned king wearing a silver claw-shaped necklace.  Loki followed suit, and the man returned it, but he was on a mission, so they did not stop and talk.  

“Both of those statements are true,” Loki spat.  “It still would have been nice to be asked.”

“Well, well.  If it isn’t the bringer of woes,” said a strong-jawed blond man with pecs to rival Thor’s.

“Steve,” Loki said as he inclined his head and scowled.

“I saw Tony’s invitation list,” Steve said with accusation in his tone.  “Who invited you?”

“We’re here as Thor’s pluses,” Chris chimed in sweetly.  The man in the ugly Christmas sweater looked down at her as if noticing her for the first time.

“Of course Thor would invite his brother,” Steve said glancing back at Loki.  “Aren’t you going to introduce me to your date?”

“Perhaps if you’d stop judging me long enough to speak, you’d already know her name,” The silvertongue hissed.  The two men glared at each other, but the little woman put a quick stop to it.

“Hi, I’m Chris,” she introduced, holding out her hand.  Steve blushed and put on a little smile.  

“Nice to meet you, Chris.  I’m Steve.”  He shook her hand as a brown-haired man in another ugly Christmas sweater joined us.  He held a drink in a metal hand.  “Chris, this is my best friend, Bucky.”  

Bucky held out his hand to the small woman, who took it kindly.  He’d been asleep for most of Loki’s crimes against Earth.  More than that, he understood the horrific torments of being controlled or influenced with no way of fighting back.  Bucky smiled warmly as he held out a hand to the trickster.  Loki took the offered hand slowly.  When he saw the familiar pain behind his eyes, he offered a small smile himself.  The two seemed to become instant friends without saying a word.

“Nice to meet you Chris, nice to meet you Loki,” he said at last, then engaged the glowering blond.

“Ah, Thor!” Chris exclaimed, heading across the room.  Loki turned to engage a small Chinese doctor.  Chris returned just as the doctor was excusing herself.  

“I totally forgot, I got you something!” Chris said excitedly.  She pulled a green santa hat out of her bag.  It had white fur trimming and a large white fur puff on the end of a point.

“What am I supposed to do with that?” Loki asked, pouting again.  

“Put it on!  It’s a hat!”  Chris explained.

“I’m not wearing that.  I actually have a sense of fashion.”  Loki walked away, ignoring the offered gift.  Chris followed, holding out the accessory.

They passed the renowned Natasha and Clint, who looked intense if a bit rosied, and ready to start comparing scars.  Natasha was still sober enough to afford the god a nasty glaring smile.

“Your fashion sense won’t be offended by this.  It perfectly matches your tunic,” Chris said when Loki finally stopped and she caught up to him.

“They don’t respect me here,” Loki sighed dramatically.  “They say I’m one of them, but they don’t respect me the same.  Am I really so different from Thor?”  They walked away toward a table laden with goodies.  Chris did not hesitate to help herself.  “It was my Seidr that helped us escape in Alfheim.  It was my silver tongue that almost got us out of battle with the frost giants.  It was my daggers that saved us on Svartalheim.  The avengers wouldn’t even exist if it wasn’t for me, my cunning and strategy.”

“Are you done yet?” Chris asked politely.  “It’s just, you really should try these cookies.  Billionaires get the best of everything.”  Loki, with his sweet tooth, was not about to turn down offered treats.  When Chris saw he was in the mood to be handed things, she held out the hat again.  “And you should try this hat on.”  She smiled coyly.

“I’m not going to wear that thing!  It looks like it was made for a child,” Loki sneered, walking away from the table.  Chris grabbed one more cheese ball before following.

“Actually, it was made for an old man.”  The little woman pointed out a fat man in a bright red suit lined with white fur, like the green cap.  A dark man with very short hair and a chiseled, pointy face gave a jolly laugh as he interacted with the actor.  Loki laughed inside, but kept a stern exterior.  Finally, he dragged his eyes away from the happy scene.

“Well I am neither a child nor an old man,” Loki pouted.  “So I don’t think it was for me.”

“Loki, you’re the oldest man I know besides your big brother.  Come on, just wear the santa hat for a little bit?”  Loki shook his head and Chris lowered it.  The red-head gasped and pointed dramatically at someone’s back.  “Is that who I think it is?”  She was suddenly extremely excited, but Loki didn’t know why.  For one thing, he didn’t know who his girlfriend was referring to.

Chris shot off away from Loki and he followed her with his gaze.  She gestured wildly and glowed a beautiful apricot as she spoke.  Loki had to hide a smile behind his hand as he watched her, amazed at his luck to have her.  The woman she talked to stood tall, bald, straight like a warrior.  But she wore an obscene amount of glitter!  Really, it was amazing she wasn’t shedding any of it!

Chris returned with her Christmas green eyes dazzling and Loki donned the hardest frown he’d ever had to wear.

“I wish someone would approach me like that,” he moaned.  

“Oh, don’t be a sourpuss,” Chris said with a playful pout.  She stroked the bridge of the mournful man’s nose.

They ambled through the party, seeing this one and that one.  They greeted more veterans.  They passed through a sea of pretty girls.  Bruce was leaning against the wall studying the fireplace.  Loki continued to pout.

“Why do you think nobody likes me?” he asked pointedly.  Chris hummed in slight irritation but answered cheerfully.

“Right now, nobody likes you because you’re being a party pooper.”  She decided to make another push before he asked about the idiom.  “Why not put the hat on?  You’ll look more festive and cheerful!”

“NO.”  He spoke firmly and she dropped her smile.  A noise at the far end of the room grabbed their attention.

“Oh, look!  It’s your brother Thor,” Chris beamed.  “Want to go talk to him.”

“No, I don’t want to do that either,” Loki hissed.

“He’s got his Christmas hat on,” Chris pointed out.  Sure enough, the blond muscle-bound god wore a red Christmas hat fringed in white, just like the green one.  “He sure looks cheerful,” Chris said with intrigue.

“So?” Loki said.  His defenses were weakening.

“So festive, having so much fun,” Chris continued with a mischievous smirk.

“Why should I care?” Loki feigned, cracking around the edges.

“He sure looks more festive than you.”  That did it.  Loki broke completely.

“Give me the infernal accessory,” Loki growled, snatching it.  He thrust it on his head, the bobble knocking against his forehead.  “There.  How do I look?”

Chris adjusted the hat so it sat on the side of head, less annoying, and kissed his sugar-pink lips with her Christmas red ones.  “You look amazing,” she beamed.

After this, Loki thought he’d better at least appear to make an effort, so he calculated how much sass and how much charm to approach the other guests.  A man who was far too jovial was performing Earth magic for a group of onlookers.  He must have been doing a good job, because they sounded impressed.

“Hey, Loki, want to go over there and show them what real magic is?”  Chris suggested.  The trickster would have liked nothing more, but time was drawing short.

“No.  I’m not going to waste my Seidr on some silly party trick.”  Chris shook her head sadly and they moved on.  A man with red skin and a golden cape caught Chris’s attention next.  She greeted him, and Loki was polite enough about it.  The little woman was drawn easily into a conversation, however.

Loki crossed his arms over his chest and leaned against the door frame to the next room.  This was the place and the time was now.  Loki’s eyes shined with mischief and a cunning half smile spread across his lips.  It started in the green box under the Christmas tree.  Loki scrambled for Chris’s attention.

“Darling, come look at this,” he said.

“Excuse me, Ms. Light.  I’ll go see what Wanda is doing.”  The android disappeared.

“You should try to get to know him,” Chris explained.  “He thinks of your brother as one of his fathers.”

“Good for him,” Loki said distracted.  “Watch.”

“Watch what?”  But no explanation was needed.  One of the presents began to glow.  

“Hey, fire,” someone called.  “I think that present’s on fire!”  Alarm spread through the crowd as they all turned to see the danger.  Tony turned from the bar with another drink in hand.  He hurried to the front of the room.  Sure enough, golden light grew slowly out of the green box reaching slowly upward.

“Friday, why isn’t the fire suppression system coming on?”  Tony asked, pulling out a small transparent tablet.

“No fire is detected, Boss,” The AI replied cooley.

“I’m looking right at it.  Check the Christmas tree,” Tony demanded.

“No fire is detected, Boss,” The AI repeated.  He spotted Loki, who stood up straight.

“You!” he barked, pointing a violent finger.  “You’re doing something… wizard.  Aren’t you?”

“Why would you accuse me?” Loki replied nonchalantly.  Chris just smiled knowingly and held her tongue.

“You weren’t even invited, Reindeer Games.  What are you doing here?” Tony looked even more livid than he was suspicious.  

There was a noise behind them and they all craned to see.  The glowing yellow light suddenly shot several feet into the air and sent little sparks everywhere!

“Friday, talk to me,” Tony demanded as he watched in horror.  Chris crossed her arms and glared at Loki with that knowing smile.

“You’re missing the fun, Darling,” he warned.  

“Just tell me it’s not deadly,” Chris demanded.

“How should I”– but the look on her face made him reconsider.  “It’s not deadly.”

They watched the show together.  The sparks grew in number, but where they lighted, nothing burned.  The box had finished blazing, but it hadn’t burnt.

“What’s going on,” someone asked above the chaos.  More people from other rooms were rushing in to see the comotion.  One of the sparks hovered over a man’s shoulder.  He and his neighbors strained to look at it.  “It’s not fire, it’s an insect.”  A few women shrieked.  Others were making observations.  

A woman with orange hair and lots of freckles known as Mrs. Stark held out her hand to catch one.  A golden light landed lightly on her palm and started to dance.  “Fairies?  Who brought fairies?”  But she thought she already knew.  She looked around for the perpetrator.  

“Are those wild forest fairies from Alfheim?”  Thor asked, placing a heavy hand on Loki’s shoulder.

“No, of course not!  I wouldn’t trust mortals with the wild ones.  These ones have been domesticated.  It’s safer that way.”  Thor smirked.

“Since when do you care about safety?”  One fluttered close to Chris’s nose and she couldn’t help but gasp and giggle.  Loki had had enough watching.

“Yes, yes, these are fairies,” he said loudly, stepping into the room with his arms spread for effect.  “I bring them to you straight from the land of the light elves, Alfheim.  Domesticated Forest fairies.  Please enjoy!  And Merry Christmas from the best gift giver on the planet!”  There was a roaring round of applause as Loki beamed and bowed.  Tony pulled him out of the spotlight.

“Alright, Loki.  How’d you get in here?” he demanded.

“The invited guests were allowed plus ones, Tony,” Mrs. Stark interrupted, her words only slightly slurred.

“Thor invited me, since I was the only Avenger to not get an invitation.  And I invited my sweetheart, Chris.”  He held out his hand and the little woman in green came to his side.

“Well, if it isn’t Christmas,” Tony chortled.  The woman with short orange hair glowered.

“She doesn’t like it when people use her full name,” Loki warned.

“Her full name?  Chris – Christine?  Christina?  Christen?  Help me out here,” Tony fumbled.

“You already said it.  How did you even know?” Chris demanded.  

“What Christmas?  Your first name is Christmas?”  Tony seemed truly surprised.  “Well, if it isn’t Christmas!” he said again.  “I’m sorry, I did not mean that in reference to your name.  That’s an expression I picked up from my mother years ago.  It has nothing to do with you.”

“Boss, it’s time for the presents to be opened,” Friday said.  Tony looked excited and jumped to attention, rubbing his hands together.  “Ok, green bean, we’ll see who’s the best gift giver on the planet!”  He jumped ahead and grabbed everyone’s attention.

Two hours later, the gifts had all been opened and the guests were showing them off to each other.  Loki turned to Chris to show her the Dictionary someone thought he needed.

“It’s not the worst gift I’ve ever received, to be honest,” he dismissed.  “Come, where’s your present?”  Chris held up empty hands.  “Wait, no one got you anything?”

“It’s alright,” Chris dismissed.  “No one knows me here.  It’s not like they expected the guest of a guest anyway.”

“This will not do.  The prettiest girl needs a gift.”  Chris tried to dismiss the idea, but Loki already seemed to have a plan.  He waved his hand and a tiny fairy appeared in it.  “This is a wishing fairy.  They are extremely rare and reserved only for monarchs and their immediate family.”  The tiny creature fluttered over to the stunned woman and perched on her shoulder.  It was whiter and brighter than the forest fairies.  “It will grant you one wish per day, but you must repeat the wish with the exact same wording three times so the fairy knows you are serious about the wish.”

Chris didn’t know what to say.  The gift was so extraordinary that she didn’t feel worthy of it, but she also didn’t know how to give it back.  Still, she thought she might test it.  She put her hand over her mouth and leaned in toward the fairy, whispering.  She said the same phrase three times, then she stood up straight and looked at her beloved.

Loki looked down at his beaming speechless beauty.  “My merry little Miss Chris,” he smiled and leaned down to give her a sweet kiss on the lips.

“It works,” she said.

“What?”  Loki looked at the wishing fairy.  “Why, the nerve!”

“Thank you, Loki,” Chris said with the most heartfelt appreciation she could muster.  Loki wrapped a hand tightly around her shoulder.

“Merry Mischief everybody, and good night!”  With that, he teleported them home.

@loki-the-fox @manip-loki @sovereignoblivious

“Perhaps if you’d stop judging me long enough to speak, you’d already know her name,” The silvertongue hissed.  The two men glared at each other, but the little woman put a quick stop to it.

“Hi, I’m Chris,” she introduced, holding out her hand.  Steve blushed and put on a little smile.  

“Nice to meet you, Chris.  I’m Steve.”  He shook her hand as a brown-haired man in another ugly Christmas sweater joined us.  He held a drink in a metal hand.  “Chris, this is my best friend, Bucky.”  

Bucky held out his hand to the small woman, who took it kindly.  He’d been asleep for most of Loki’s crimes against Earth.  More than that, he understood the horrific torments of being controlled or influenced with no way of fighting back.  Bucky smiled warmly as he held out a hand to the trickster.  Loki took the offered hand slowly.  When he saw the familiar pain behind his eyes, he offered a small smile himself.  The two seemed to become instant friends without saying a word.

“Nice to meet you Chris, nice to meet you Loki,” he said at last, then engaged the glowering blond.

“Ah, Thor!” Chris exclaimed, heading across the room.  Loki turned to engage a small Chinese doctor.  Chris returned just as the doctor was excusing herself.  

“I totally forgot, I got you something!” Chris said excitedly.  She pulled a green santa hat out of her bag.  It had white fur trimming and a large white fur puff on the end of a point.

“What am I supposed to do with that?” Loki asked, pouting again.  

“Put it on!  It’s a hat!”  Chris explained.

“I’m not wearing that.  I actually have a sense of fashion.”  Loki walked away, ignoring the offered gift.  Chris followed, holding out the accessory.

They passed the renowned Natasha and Clint, who looked intense if a bit rosied, and ready to start comparing scars.  Natasha was still sober enough to afford the god a nasty glaring smile.

“Your fashion sense won’t be offended by this.  It perfectly matches your tunic,” Chris said when Loki finally stopped and she caught up to him.

“They don’t respect me here,” Loki sighed dramatically.  “They say I’m one of them, but they don’t respect me the same.  Am I really so different from Thor?”  They walked away toward a table laden with goodies.  Chris did not hesitate to help herself.  “It was my Seidr that helped us escape in Alfheim.  It was my silver tongue that almost got us out of battle with the frost giants.  It was my daggers that saved us on Svartalheim.  The avengers wouldn’t even exist if it wasn’t for me, my cunning and strategy.”

“Are you done yet?” Chris asked politely.  “It’s just, you really should try these cookies.  Billionaires get the best of everything.”  Loki, with his sweet tooth, was not about to turn down offered treats.  When Chris saw he was in the mood to be handed things, she held out the hat again.  “And you should try this hat on.”  She smiled coyly.

“I’m not going to wear that thing!  It looks like it was made for a child,” Loki sneered, walking away from the table.  Chris grabbed one more cheese ball before following.

“Actually, it was made for an old man.”  The little woman pointed out a fat man in a bright red suit lined with white fur, like the green cap.  A dark man with very short hair and a chiseled, pointy face gave a jolly laugh as he interacted with the actor.  Loki laughed inside, but kept a stern exterior.  Finally, he dragged his eyes away from the happy scene.

“Well I am neither a child nor an old man,” Loki pouted.  “So I don’t think it was for me.”

“Loki, you’re the oldest man I know besides your big brother.  Come on, just wear the santa hat for a little bit?”  Loki shook his head and Chris lowered it.  The red-head gasped and pointed dramatically at someone’s back.  “Is that who I think it is?”  She was suddenly extremely excited, but Loki didn’t know why.  For one thing, he didn’t know who his girlfriend was referring to.

Chris shot off away from Loki and he followed her with his gaze.  She gestured wildly and glowed a beautiful apricot as she spoke.  Loki had to hide a smile behind his hand as he watched her, amazed at his luck to have her.  The woman she talked to stood tall, bald, straight like a warrior.  But she wore an obscene amount of glitter!  Really, it was amazing she wasn’t shedding any of it!

Chris returned with her Christmas green eyes dazzling and Loki donned the hardest frown he’d ever had to wear.

“I wish someone would approach me like that,” he moaned.  

“Oh, don’t be a sourpuss,” Chris said with a playful pout.  She stroked the bridge of the mournful man’s nose.

They ambled through the party, seeing this one and that one.  They greeted more veterans.  They passed through a sea of pretty girls.  Bruce was leaning against the wall studying the fireplace.  Loki continued to pout.

“Why do you think nobody likes me?” he asked pointedly.  Chris hummed in slight irritation but answered cheerfully.

“Right now, nobody likes you because you’re being a party pooper.”  She decided to make another push before he asked about the idiom.  “Why not put the hat on?  You’ll look more festive and cheerful!”

“NO.”  He spoke firmly and she dropped her smile.  A noise at the far end of the room grabbed their attention.

“Oh, look!  It’s your brother Thor,” Chris beamed.  “Want to go talk to him.”

“No, I don’t want to do that either,” Loki hissed.

“He’s got his Christmas hat on,” Chris pointed out.  Sure enough, the blond muscle-bound god wore a red Christmas hat fringed in white, just like the green one.  “He sure looks cheerful,” Chris said with intrigue.

“So?” Loki said.  His defenses were weakening.

“So festive, having so much fun,” Chris continued with a mischievous smirk.

“Why should I care?” Loki feigned, cracking around the edges.

“He sure looks more festive than you.”  That did it.  Loki broke completely.

“Give me the infernal accessory,” Loki growled, snatching it.  He thrust it on his head, the bobble knocking against his forehead.  “There.  How do I look?”

Chris adjusted the hat so it sat on the side of head, less annoying, and kissed his sugar-pink lips with her Christmas red ones.  “You look amazing,” she beamed.

After this, Loki thought he’d better at least appear to make an effort, so he calculated how much sass and how much charm to approach the other guests.  A man who was far too jovial was performing Earth magic for a group of onlookers.  He must have been doing a good job, because they sounded impressed.

“Hey, Loki, want to go over there and show them what real magic is?”  Chris suggested.  The trickster would have liked nothing more, but time was drawing short.

“No.  I’m not going to waste my Seidr on some silly party trick.”  Chris shook her head sadly and they moved on.  A man with red skin and a golden cape caught Chris’s attention next.  She greeted him, and Loki was polite enough about it.  The little woman was drawn easily into a conversation, however.

Loki crossed his arms over his chest and leaned against the door frame to the next room.  This was the place and the time was now.  Loki’s eyes shined with mischief and a cunning half smile spread across his lips.  It started in the green box under the Christmas tree.  Loki scrambled for Chris’s attention.

“Darling, come look at this,” he said.

“Excuse me, Ms. Light.  I’ll go see what Wanda is doing.”  The android disappeared.

“You should try to get to know him,” Chris explained.  “He thinks of your brother as one of his fathers.”

“Good for him,” Loki said distracted.  “Watch.”

“Watch what?”  But no explanation was needed.  One of the presents began to glow.  

“Hey, fire,” someone called.  “I think that present’s on fire!”  Alarm spread through the crowd as they all turned to see the danger.  Tony turned from the bar with another drink in hand.  He hurried to the front of the room.  Sure enough, golden light grew slowly out of the green box reaching slowly upward.

“Friday, why isn’t the fire suppression system coming on?”  Tony asked, pulling out a small transparent tablet.

“No fire is detected, Boss,” The AI replied cooley.

“I’m looking right at it.  Check the Christmas tree,” Tony demanded.

“No fire is detected, Boss,” The AI repeated.  He spotted Loki, who stood up straight.

“You!” he barked, pointing a violent finger.  “You’re doing something… wizard.  Aren’t you?”

“Why would you accuse me?” Loki replied nonchalantly.  Chris just smiled knowingly and held her tongue.

“You weren’t even invited, Reindeer Games.  What are you doing here?” Tony looked even more livid than he was suspicious.  

There was a noise behind them and they all craned to see.  The glowing yellow light suddenly shot several feet into the air and sent little sparks everywhere!

“Friday, talk to me,” Tony demanded as he watched in horror.  Chris crossed her arms and glared at Loki with that knowing smile.

“You’re missing the fun, Darling,” he warned.  

“Just tell me it’s not deadly,” Chris demanded.

“How should I”– but the look on her face made him reconsider.  “It’s not deadly.”

They watched the show together.  The sparks grew in number, but where they lighted, nothing burned.  The box had finished blazing, but it hadn’t burnt.

“What’s going on,” someone asked above the chaos.  More people from other rooms were rushing in to see the comotion.  One of the sparks hovered over a man’s shoulder.  He and his neighbors strained to look at it.  “It’s not fire, it’s an insect.”  A few women shrieked.  Others were making observations.  

A woman with orange hair and lots of freckles known as Mrs. Stark held out her hand to catch one.  A golden light landed lightly on her palm and started to dance.  “Fairies?  Who brought fairies?”  But she thought she already knew.  She looked around for the perpetrator.  

“Are those wild forest fairies from Alfheim?”  Thor asked, placing a heavy hand on Loki’s shoulder.

“No, of course not!  I wouldn’t trust mortals with the wild ones.  These ones have been domesticated.  It’s safer that way.”  Thor smirked.

“Since when do you care about safety?”  One fluttered close to Chris’s nose and she couldn’t help but gasp and giggle.  Loki had had enough watching.

“Yes, yes, these are fairies,” he said loudly, stepping into the room with his arms spread for effect.  “I bring them to you straight from the land of the light elves, Alfheim.  Domesticated Forest fairies.  Please enjoy!  And Merry Christmas from the best gift giver on the planet!”  There was a roaring round of applause as Loki beamed and bowed.  Tony pulled him out of the spotlight.

“Alright, Loki.  How’d you get in here?” he demanded.

“The invited guests were allowed plus ones, Tony,” Mrs. Stark interrupted, her words only slightly slurred.

“Thor invited me, since I was the only Avenger to not get an invitation.  And I invited my sweetheart, Chris.”  He held out his hand and the little woman in green came to his side.

“Well, if it isn’t Christmas,” Tony chortled.  The woman with short orange hair glowered.

“She doesn’t like it when people use her full name,” Loki warned.

“Her full name?  Chris – Christine?  Christina?  Christen?  Help me out here,” Tony fumbled.

“You already said it.  How did you even know?” Chris demanded.  

“What Christmas?  Your first name is Christmas?”  Tony seemed truly surprised.  “Well, if it isn’t Christmas!” he said again.  “I’m sorry, I did not mean that in reference to your name.  That’s an expression I picked up from my mother years ago.  It has nothing to do with you.”

“Boss, it’s time for the presents to be opened,” Friday said.  Tony looked excited and jumped to attention, rubbing his hands together.  “Ok, green bean, we’ll see who’s the best gift giver on the planet!”  He jumped ahead and grabbed everyone’s attention.

Two hours later, the gifts had all been opened and the guests were showing them off to each other.  Loki turned to Chris to show her the Dictionary someone thought he needed.

“It’s not the worst gift I’ve ever received, to be honest,” he dismissed.  “Come, where’s your present?”  Chris held up empty hands.  “Wait, no one got you anything?”

“It’s alright,” Chris dismissed.  “No one knows me here.  It’s not like they expected the guest of a guest anyway.”

“This will not do.  The prettiest girl needs a gift.”  Chris tried to dismiss the idea, but Loki already seemed to have a plan.  He waved his hand and a tiny fairy appeared in it.  “This is a wishing fairy.  They are extremely rare and reserved only for monarchs and their immediate family.”  The tiny creature fluttered over to the stunned woman and perched on her shoulder.  It was whiter and brighter than the forest fairies.  “It will grant you one wish per day, but you must repeat the wish with the exact same wording three times so the fairy knows you are serious about the wish.”

Chris didn’t know what to say.  The gift was so extraordinary that she didn’t feel worthy of it, but she also didn’t know how to give it back.  Still, she thought she might test it.  She put her hand over her mouth and leaned in toward the fairy, whispering.  She said the same phrase three times, then she stood up straight and looked at her beloved.

Loki looked down at his beaming speechless beauty.  “My merry little Miss Chris,” he smiled and leaned down to give her a sweet kiss on the lips.

“It works,” she said.

“What?”  Loki looked at the wishing fairy.  “Why, the nerve!”

“Thank you, Loki,” Chris said with the most heartfelt appreciation she could muster.  Loki wrapped a hand tightly around her shoulder.

“Merry Mischief everybody, and good night!”  With that, he teleported them home.

An old man in a veteran’s cap and a young blond woman hurried into the elevator behind them.  People were everywhere, standing, chatting and holding drinks.  They passed a man with braces on his knees and back.  He was wearing nice slacks and a winter-themed polo shirt.  “Boom, ya’ lookin’ fo dis?” he said to a round of chuckles.  Apparently, his story had been funny.

“I don’t see why I didn’t receive an invitation directly from Tony?” Loki whined for the um-teenth time.  “Every one of them agreed I was as much an Avenger now as any of them.  Yet, they still don’t trust me.”

“It’s all your titles,” Chris explained absently, shaking the hand of a tipsy dignitary.  “Liesmith, god of mischief, bringer of chaos.  They’re afraid of you.”  She spoke lightly enough, but really she hoped her words would comfort the gloomy god.  She was seldom afforded the opportunity to attend such illustrious events and she was determined to enjoy herself, even if Loki didn’t.

“It’s alright,” Chris dismissed.  “No one knows me here.  It’s not like they expected the guest of a guest anyway.”

“This will not do.  The prettiest girl needs a gift.”  Chris tried to dismiss the idea, but Loki already seemed to have a plan.  He waved his hand and a tiny fairy appeared in it.  “This is a wishing fairy.  They are extremely rare and reserved only for monarchs and their immediate family.”  The tiny creature fluttered over to the stunned woman and perched on her shoulder.  It was whiter and brighter than the forest fairies.  “It will grant you one wish per day, but you must repeat the wish with the exact same wording three times so the fairy knows you are serious about the wish.”

Chris didn’t know what to say.  The gift was so extraordinary that she didn’t feel worthy of it, but she also didn’t know how to give it back.  Still, she thought she might test it.  She put her hand over her mouth and leaned in toward the fairy, whispering.  She said the same phrase three times, then she stood up straight and looked at her beloved.

Loki looked down at his beaming speechless beauty.  “My merry little Miss Chris,” he smiled and leaned down to give her a sweet kiss on the lips.

“It works,” she said.

“What?”  Loki looked at the wishing fairy.  “Why, the nerve!”

“Thank you, Loki,” Chris said with the most heartfelt appreciation she could muster.  Loki wrapped a hand tightly around her shoulder.

“Merry Mischief everybody, and good night!”  With that, he teleported them home.

For River’s Holiday Challenge

image by @maniploki

Chris exited the elevator in a short green dress and black leggings, orange fringe falling in her face again, arm looped around her boyfriend.  It had taken some effort, but she finally managed to convince Loki to come to the party.  He had found a nice green tunic and black slacks.  His shoulder-length raven curls looked immaculate against the tunic.

An old man in a veteran’s cap and a young blond woman hurried into the elevator behind them.  People were everywhere, standing, chatting and holding drinks.  They passed a man with braces on his knees and back.  He was wearing nice slacks and a winter-themed polo shirt.  “Boom, ya’ lookin’ fo dis?” he said to a round of chuckles.  Apparently, his story had been funny.

“I don’t see why I didn’t receive an invitation directly from Tony?” Loki whined for the um-teenth time.  “Every one of them agreed I was as much an Avenger now as any of them.  Yet, they still don’t trust me.”

“It’s all your titles,” Chris explained absently, shaking the hand of a tipsy dignitary.  “Liesmith, god of mischief, bringer of chaos.  They’re afraid of you.”  She spoke lightly enough, but really she hoped her words would comfort the gloomy god.  She was seldom afforded the opportunity to attend such illustrious events and she was determined to enjoy herself, even if Loki didn’t.

“Yes, well, the god of thunder sounds equally as frightening, along with his less familiar name, cosmic oaf.”  Loki smiled sardonically as they passed into the first room from the elevator hall.  They passed a wall-sized TV and several teenagers sitting on fluffy furniture.

“You can’t do that, Peter,” a pretty girl cried as she laughed.

“Oh, yes I can, Princess,” Peter replied.  These two were holding controllers while the wall-screen showed a split view of two cars.

“Yeah, you show her Peter,” said a chubby Asian, supporting his best friend.  A brown-haired youth playing with glowing red mist seemed to support the princess.

“I should in with that group,” Loki pouted as they left the teens behind.  “I’m closer comparatively to their age than to yours.  Yet they never invite me to – what’s the Earth vernacular – hang out?”

“They used to invite you, but you kept turning them down, remember?  Something about them being immature and primitive?”  Chris took a moment to bow to a dark-skinned king wearing a silver claw-shaped necklace.  Loki followed suit, and the man returned it, but he was on a mission, so they did not stop and talk.  

“Both of those statements are true,” Loki spat.  “It still would have been nice to be asked.”

“Well, well.  If it isn’t the bringer of woes,” said a strong-jawed blond man with pecs to rival Thor’s.

“Steve,” Loki said as he inclined his head and scowled.

“I saw Tony’s invitation list,” Steve said with accusation in his tone.  “Who invited you?”

“We’re here as Thor’s pluses,” Chris chimed in sweetly.  The man in the ugly Christmas sweater looked down at her as if noticing her for the first time.

“Of course Thor would invite his brother,” Steve said glancing back at Loki.  “Aren’t you going to introduce me to your date?”

“Perhaps if you’d stop judging me long enough to speak, you’d already know her name,” The silvertongue hissed.  The two men glared at each other, but the little woman put a quick stop to it.

“Hi, I’m Chris,” she introduced, holding out her hand.  Steve blushed and put on a little smile.  

“Nice to meet you, Chris.  I’m Steve.”  He shook her hand as a brown-haired man in another ugly Christmas sweater joined us.  He held a drink in a metal hand.  “Chris, this is my best friend, Bucky.”  

Bucky held out his hand to the small woman, who took it kindly.  He’d been asleep for most of Loki’s crimes against Earth.  More than that, he understood the horrific torments of being controlled or influenced with no way of fighting back.  Bucky smiled warmly as he held out a hand to the trickster.  Loki took the offered hand slowly.  When he saw the familiar pain behind his eyes, he offered a small smile himself.  The two seemed to become instant friends without saying a word.

“Nice to meet you Chris, nice to meet you Loki,” he said at last, then engaged the glowering blond.

“Ah, Thor!” Chris exclaimed, heading across the room.  Loki turned to engage a small Chinese doctor.  Chris returned just as the doctor was excusing herself.  

“I totally forgot, I got you something!” Chris said excitedly.  She pulled a green santa hat out of her bag.  It had white fur trimming and a large white fur puff on the end of a point.

“What am I supposed to do with that?” Loki asked, pouting again.  

“Put it on!  It’s a hat!”  Chris explained.

“I’m not wearing that.  I actually have a sense of fashion.”  Loki walked away, ignoring the offered gift.  Chris followed, holding out the accessory.

They passed the renowned Natasha and Clint, who looked intense if a bit rosied, and ready to start comparing scars.  Natasha was still sober enough to afford the god a nasty glaring smile.

“Your fashion sense won’t be offended by this.  It perfectly matches your tunic,” Chris said when Loki finally stopped and she caught up to him.

“They don’t respect me here,” Loki sighed dramatically.  “They say I’m one of them, but they don’t respect me the same.  Am I really so different from Thor?”  They walked away toward a table laden with goodies.  Chris did not hesitate to help herself.  “It was my Seidr that helped us escape in Alfheim.  It was my silver tongue that almost got us out of battle with the frost giants.  It was my daggers that saved us on Svartalheim.  The avengers wouldn’t even exist if it wasn’t for me, my cunning and strategy.”

“Are you done yet?” Chris asked politely.  “It’s just, you really should try these cookies.  Billionaires get the best of everything.”  Loki, with his sweet tooth, was not about to turn down offered treats.  When Chris saw he was in the mood to be handed things, she held out the hat again.  “And you should try this hat on.”  She smiled coyly.

“I’m not going to wear that thing!  It looks like it was made for a child,” Loki sneered, walking away from the table.  Chris grabbed one more cheese ball before following.

“Actually, it was made for an old man.”  The little woman pointed out a fat man in a bright red suit lined with white fur, like the green cap.  A dark man with very short hair and a chiseled, pointy face gave a jolly laugh as he interacted with the actor.  Loki laughed inside, but kept a stern exterior.  Finally, he dragged his eyes away from the happy scene.

“Well I am neither a child nor an old man,” Loki pouted.  “So I don’t think it was for me.”

“Loki, you’re the oldest man I know besides your big brother.  Come on, just wear the santa hat for a little bit?”  Loki shook his head and Chris lowered it.  The red-head gasped and pointed dramatically at someone’s back.  “Is that who I think it is?”  She was suddenly extremely excited, but Loki didn’t know why.  For one thing, he didn’t know who his girlfriend was referring to.

Chris shot off away from Loki and he followed her with his gaze.  She gestured wildly and glowed a beautiful apricot as she spoke.  Loki had to hide a smile behind his hand as he watched her, amazed at his luck to have her.  The woman she talked to stood tall, bald, straight like a warrior.  But she wore an obscene amount of glitter!  Really, it was amazing she wasn’t shedding any of it!

Chris returned with her Christmas green eyes dazzling and Loki donned the hardest frown he’d ever had to wear.

“I wish someone would approach me like that,” he moaned.  

“Oh, don’t be a sourpuss,” Chris said with a playful pout.  She stroked the bridge of the mournful man’s nose.

They ambled through the party, seeing this one and that one.  They greeted more veterans.  They passed through a sea of pretty girls.  Bruce was leaning against the wall studying the fireplace.  Loki continued to pout.

“Why do you think nobody likes me?” he asked pointedly.  Chris hummed in slight irritation but answered cheerfully.

“Right now, nobody likes you because you’re being a party pooper.”  She decided to make another push before he asked about the idiom.  “Why not put the hat on?  You’ll look more festive and cheerful!”

“NO.”  He spoke firmly and she dropped her smile.  A noise at the far end of the room grabbed their attention.

“Oh, look!  It’s your brother Thor,” Chris beamed.  “Want to go talk to him.”

“No, I don’t want to do that either,” Loki hissed.

“He’s got his Christmas hat on,” Chris pointed out.  Sure enough, the blond muscle-bound god wore a red Christmas hat fringed in white, just like the green one.  “He sure looks cheerful,” Chris said with intrigue.

“So?” Loki said.  His defenses were weakening.

“So festive, having so much fun,” Chris continued with a mischievous smirk.

“Why should I care?” Loki feigned, cracking around the edges.

“He sure looks more festive than you.”  That did it.  Loki broke completely.

“Give me the infernal accessory,” Loki growled, snatching it.  He thrust it on his head, the bobble knocking against his forehead.  “There.  How do I look?”

Chris adjusted the hat so it sat on the side of head, less annoying, and kissed his sugar-pink lips with her Christmas red ones.  “You look amazing,” she beamed.

After this, Loki thought he’d better at least appear to make an effort, so he calculated how much sass and how much charm to approach the other guests.  A man who was far too jovial was performing Earth magic for a group of onlookers.  He must have been doing a good job, because they sounded impressed.

“Hey, Loki, want to go over there and show them what real magic is?”  Chris suggested.  The trickster would have liked nothing more, but time was drawing short.

“No.  I’m not going to waste my Seidr on some silly party trick.”  Chris shook her head sadly and they moved on.  A man with red skin and a golden cape caught Chris’s attention next.  She greeted him, and Loki was polite enough about it.  The little woman was drawn easily into a conversation, however.

Loki crossed his arms over his chest and leaned against the door frame to the next room.  This was the place and the time was now.  Loki’s eyes shined with mischief and a cunning half smile spread across his lips.  It started in the green box under the Christmas tree.  Loki scrambled for Chris’s attention.

“Darling, come look at this,” he said.

“Excuse me, Ms. Light.  I’ll go see what Wanda is doing.”  The android disappeared.

“You should try to get to know him,” Chris explained.  “He thinks of your brother as one of his fathers.”

“Good for him,” Loki said distracted.  “Watch.”

“Watch what?”  But no explanation was needed.  One of the presents began to glow.  

“Hey, fire,” someone called.  “I think that present’s on fire!”  Alarm spread through the crowd as they all turned to see the danger.  Tony turned from the bar with another drink in hand.  He hurried to the front of the room.  Sure enough, golden light grew slowly out of the green box reaching slowly upward.

“Friday, why isn’t the fire suppression system coming on?”  Tony asked, pulling out a small transparent tablet.

“No fire is detected, Boss,” The AI replied cooley.

“I’m looking right at it.  Check the Christmas tree,” Tony demanded.

“No fire is detected, Boss,” The AI repeated.  He spotted Loki, who stood up straight.

“You!” he barked, pointing a violent finger.  “You’re doing something… wizard.  Aren’t you?”

“Why would you accuse me?” Loki replied nonchalantly.  Chris just smiled knowingly and held her tongue.

“You weren’t even invited, Reindeer Games.  What are you doing here?” Tony looked even more livid than he was suspicious.  

There was a noise behind them and they all craned to see.  The glowing yellow light suddenly shot several feet into the air and sent little sparks everywhere!

“Friday, talk to me,” Tony demanded as he watched in horror.  Chris crossed her arms and glared at Loki with that knowing smile.

“You’re missing the fun, Darling,” he warned.  

“Just tell me it’s not deadly,” Chris demanded.

“How should I”– but the look on her face made him reconsider.  “It’s not deadly.”

They watched the show together.  The sparks grew in number, but where they lighted, nothing burned.  The box had finished blazing, but it hadn’t burnt.

“What’s going on,” someone asked above the chaos.  More people from other rooms were rushing in to see the comotion.  One of the sparks hovered over a man’s shoulder.  He and his neighbors strained to look at it.  “It’s not fire, it’s an insect.”  A few women shrieked.  Others were making observations.  

A woman with orange hair and lots of freckles known as Mrs. Stark held out her hand to catch one.  A golden light landed lightly on her palm and started to dance.  “Fairies?  Who brought fairies?”  But she thought she already knew.  She looked around for the perpetrator.  

“Are those wild forest fairies from Alfheim?”  Thor asked, placing a heavy hand on Loki’s shoulder.

“No, of course not!  I wouldn’t trust mortals with the wild ones.  These ones have been domesticated.  It’s safer that way.”  Thor smirked.

“Since when do you care about safety?”  One fluttered close to Chris’s nose and she couldn’t help but gasp and giggle.  Loki had had enough watching.

“Yes, yes, these are fairies,” he said loudly, stepping into the room with his arms spread for effect.  “I bring them to you straight from the land of the light elves, Alfheim.  Domesticated Forest fairies.  Please enjoy!  And Merry Christmas from the best gift giver on the planet!”  There was a roaring round of applause as Loki beamed and bowed.  Tony pulled him out of the spotlight.

“Alright, Loki.  How’d you get in here?” he demanded.

“The invited guests were allowed plus ones, Tony,” Mrs. Stark interrupted, her words only slightly slurred.

“Thor invited me, since I was the only Avenger to not get an invitation.  And I invited my sweetheart, Chris.”  He held out his hand and the little woman in green came to his side.

“Well, if it isn’t Christmas,” Tony chortled.  The woman with short orange hair glowered.

“She doesn’t like it when people use her full name,” Loki warned.

“Her full name?  Chris – Christine?  Christina?  Christen?  Help me out here,” Tony fumbled.

“You already said it.  How did you even know?” Chris demanded.  

“What Christmas?  Your first name is Christmas?”  Tony seemed truly surprised.  “Well, if it isn’t Christmas!” he said again.  “I’m sorry, I did not mean that in reference to your name.  That’s an expression I picked up from my mother years ago.  It has nothing to do with you.”

“Boss, it’s time for the presents to be opened,” Friday said.  Tony looked excited and jumped to attention, rubbing his hands together.  “Ok, green bean, we’ll see who’s the best gift giver on the planet!”  He jumped ahead and grabbed everyone’s attention.

Two hours later, the gifts had all been opened and the guests were showing them off to each other.  Loki turned to Chris to show her the Dictionary someone thought he needed.

“It’s not the worst gift I’ve ever received, to be honest,” he dismissed.  “Come, where’s your present?”  Chris held up empty hands.  “Wait, no one got you anything?”

“It’s alright,” Chris dismissed.  “No one knows me here.  It’s not like they expected the guest of a guest anyway.”

“This will not do.  The prettiest girl needs a gift.”  Chris tried to dismiss the idea, but Loki already seemed to have a plan.  He waved his hand and a tiny fairy appeared in it.  “This is a wishing fairy.  They are extremely rare and reserved only for monarchs and their immediate family.”  The tiny creature fluttered over to the stunned woman and perched on her shoulder.  It was whiter and brighter than the forest fairies.  “It will grant you one wish per day, but you must repeat the wish with the exact same wording three times so the fairy knows you are serious about the wish.”

Chris didn’t know what to say.  The gift was so extraordinary that she didn’t feel worthy of it, but she also didn’t know how to give it back.  Still, she thought she might test it.  She put her hand over her mouth and leaned in toward the fairy, whispering.  She said the same phrase three times, then she stood up straight and looked at her beloved.

Loki looked down at his beaming speechless beauty.  “My merry little Miss Chris,” he smiled and leaned down to give her a sweet kiss on the lips.

“It works,” she said.

“What?”  Loki looked at the wishing fairy.  “Why, the nerve!”

“Thank you, Loki,” Chris said with the most heartfelt appreciation she could muster.  Loki wrapped a hand tightly around her shoulder.

“Merry Mischief everybody, and good night!”  With that, he teleported them home.
